nodes.bodyText: Let's not make it generic so it could be used in other places too. Like system tables.
we should also inject ConnectorSecurityContext so it could be used instead of null. It could be artificial but user should the one passed by us when checking the access.

I would name it as AccessControlConnectorAdapter

Or do something similar?

+

+        assertAllMethodsOverridden(ConnectorAccessControl.class, ConnectorAccessControlForProcedures.class);

nodes.bodyText: Create separate procedure for your new test, otherwise it is hard to tell why testExecuteNoPermission passes
There is plenty of code copied from testExecuteNoPermission can you please somehow unify that?
For an internal class, the initial name doesn't matter, as we can always rename it. But we could start with a generic name like InjectedConnectorAccessControl.

We can do this as two filters, which makes it a bit easier to read and modify later
.filter(type -> !ConnectorSession.class.isAssignableFrom(type))
.filter(type -> !ConnectorAccessControl.class.isAssignableFrom(type))
I would say "must" rather than "should" since this is a requirement (and "should" implies a recommendation)

We should probably throw IllegalStateException here if there are multiple filters, since picking the first one would be discarding the other row filters. Ideally, the engine should probably analyze and combine them into a single expression, but we don't need to worry about this now.
Use two filters. See comment above.

@@ -57,7 +58,7 @@ public Procedure(String schema, String name, List<Argument> arguments, MethodHan
         checkArgument(methodHandle.type().returnType() == void.class, "Method must return void");
 
         long parameterCount = methodHandle.type().parameterList().stream()
-                .filter(type -> !ConnectorSession.class.isAssignableFrom(type))
+                .filter(type -> !(ConnectorSession.class.isAssignableFrom(type) || ConnectorAccessControl.class.isAssignableFrom(type)))

nodes.bodyText: Use SchemaTableName to format the error message, as above. Maybe extract a variable for the existing new SchemaTableName(...)
Actually, let's not wrap the error message here. The original message "cannot insert into table" is reasonable, and the stack trace might provide useful information. Same goes for the others.
Same comment. The original error message will be good if we have an explicit access check for statistics.
I think it can be supported when accessControl returns Optional.empty()
I think it can be supported when accessControl returns Optional.empty()

This check is actually reversed (as is the existing one for ConnectorSession). It would succeed if the parameter type is a subclass of ConnectorAccessControl, which would cause an error when the method is invoked (since the instance would not match).
I think this should be switched to equality, since we wouldn't want to inject or instance for any superclass either (in this case only Object).
We should also fix the ConnectorSession check, but that can be a separate PR (or feel free to throw another commit on this PR).
Same comment as above about isAssignableFrom

nodes.bodyText:
Let's make this checkCanInsertIntoTable to match ANALYZE, since we're not deleting data. This would mean a user who has insert permission can drop stats and then run analyze.
From the connector's point of view, analyze actually overwrites (i.e. deletes) the existing statistics, so drop stats can be thought of as a limited form of analyze.
Separately, we should probably add a new permission for analyze.

commit.message: Minor cleanup in checks involving ConnectorSession for Procedure
